title: Wikiwand - Naturopathy
description: Naturopathy, or naturopathic medicine, is a form of alternative medicine. A wide array of pseudoscientific practices branded as "natural", "non-invasive", or promoting "self-healing" are employed by its practitioners, who are known as naturopaths. Difficult to generalize, these treatments range from outright quackery, like homeopathy, to widely accepted practices like certain forms of psychotherapy. The ideology and methods of naturopathy are based on vitalism and folk medicine rather than evidence-based medicine, although practitioners may use techniques supported by evidence.
cleaned_text: Naturopathy Form of alternative medicine / From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Dear Wikiwand AI, let's keep it short by simply answering these key questions: Can you list the top facts and stats about Naturopathic medicine? Summarize this article for a 10 years old Naturopathy, or naturopathic medicine, is a form of [alternative medicine](/en/Alternative_medicine). [[1]](#cite_note-Gale_Frey-1) A wide array of [pseudoscientific](/en/Pseudoscience) practices branded as "natural", "non-invasive", or promoting "self-healing" are employed by its practitioners, who are known as naturopaths. Difficult to generalize, these treatments range from outright [quackery](/en/Quackery), like [homeopathy](/en/Homeopathy), to widely accepted practices like certain forms of [psychotherapy](/en/Psychotherapy). [[2]](#cite_note-Baran2014-2) [[3]](#cite_note-oxcompus-3) [[4]](#cite_note-4) The ideology and methods of naturopathy are based on [vitalism](/en/Vitalism) and [folk medicine](/en/Folk_medicine) rather than [evidence-based medicine](/en/Evidence-based_medicine), although practitioners against following [modern medical practices](/en/Medicine), including but not practice relies on unscientific notions, often leading naturopaths to diagnoses and treatments that have no factual merit. [[12]](#cite_note-atwood2003-12) [[13]](#cite_note-AAFP-13) Naturopathy is considered by the [medical profession](/en/Medical_profession) to be ineffective and harmful, raising [ethical](/en/Medical_ethics) issues about its practice. [[12]](#cite_note-atwood2003-12) [[14]](#cite_note-14) [[15]](#cite_note-tot-15) In addition to condemnations and criticism from the medical community, such as the [American Cancer Society](/en/American_Cancer_Society), [[16]](#cite_note-ACS-2009-16) naturopaths have repeatedly been denounced as and accused of being [charlatans](/en/Charlatan) and practicing quackery. [[12]](#cite_note-atwood2003-12) [[17]](#cite_note-atwood2004-17) [[18]](#cite_note-Barrett-Naturopathy-18) [[19]](#cite_note-Harvey2015-19) [[20]](#cite_note-Chivers2014-20) [[21]](#cite_note-Caulfield2013-21) Naturopaths frequently campaign for legal recognition in the United States. Naturopathy is illegal in two [U.S. states](/en/U.S._states) and tightly regulated in many others. Some states have lax regulations, however, and may allow naturopaths to perform minor surgery or even prescribe drugs. While some schools exist for naturopaths, and some jurisdictions allow such practitioners to call themselves doctors, the lack of accreditation, scientific medical training, and quantifiable positive results means they lack the competency of true medical doctors.
